title: Florida mayor not offended by Bidenâ€™s â€˜salty languageâ€™ on live microphone

text:
Good morning.The Biden administration and its supporters have reacted angrily to the Opec+ decision to cut oil production, seeing it as a rebuff to the US presidentâ€™s efforts to improve relations with Saudi Arabia.The White House made clear that it viewed the decision by the oil production cartel, in which the plus sign represents the inclusion of Russia, to reduce daily production by 2m barrels, as a geopolitical move, and a slight to Biden, who is seeking to cut Russian revenues and keep the petrol price down before Novemberâ€™s congressional elections.He angered his supporters by visiting Jeddah in July, where he was pictured greeting Mohammed bin Salman with a fist-bump, in the hope of increased production and lower oil prices, despite US intelligence findings that the kingdomâ€™s de facto ruler was behind the 2018 murder of the Saudi dissident and Washington Post columnist Jamal Khashoggi.White House spokesperson Karin Jean-Pierre said: â€œItâ€™s clear that Opec+ is aligning with Russia with todayâ€™s announcement.â€
What does Biden think? A statement from the national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, and the director of the National Economic Council, Brian Deese, said the president was â€œdisappointed by the shortsighted decision â€¦ while the global economy is dealing with the continued negative impact of Putinâ€™s invasion of Ukraineâ€.
Thailand shooting: 22 children among 34 killed in preschool attackThe preschool centre in north-eastern Thailand was attacked by a gunman who also killed himself and his family. Photograph: AP / Viral PressThirty-four people have been killed, including 22 children, in a mass shooting at a preschool centre in a north-eastern province of Thailand, police have said.About 30 children were at the centre when the gunman entered the building at 12.30pm local time, during the childrenâ€™s nap time, police and local officials said. The attacker, a former policeman, also killed his wife and child before shooting himself dead.Jidapa Boonsom, a district official, told Reuters the attacker first shot four or five members of staff, including a teacher who was eight months pregnant. â€œAt first people thought it was fireworks,â€ she added.Videos posted on social media showed sheets covering what appeared to be the bodies of children lying in pools of blood at the centre in the town of Uthai Sawan in the north-eastern province of Nong Bua Lamphu.
Do police know what the attackerâ€™s motivation was? Maj Gen Paisan Leusomboon, the deputy police commissioner, told Thai channel PPTV HD 36 that the perpetrator had recently been fired from work and had drug addiction problems.
Are mass shootings common in Thailand? No. They are rare, but in 2020 a soldier angry over a property deal killed 29 people and wounded 57 in a rampage that spanned four locations.
California family who were kidnapped at gunpoint found deadEight-month-old Aroohi Dheri, her mother, Jasleen Kaur, father Jasdeep Singh and uncle Amandeep Singh have been found dead after a kidnapping. Photograph: Andrew Kuhn/APA family who were kidnapped at gunpoint from their central California business two days ago have been found dead.A farmworker found the bodies of a baby girl, her parents and her uncle at an orchard in Merced County, according to the local sheriff.â€œOur worst fears have been confirmed,â€ Sheriff Vern Warnke told reporters on Wednesday night.The announcement came after authorities released footage from a surveillance camera of a man kidnapping eight-month-old Aroohi Dheri, her mother, Jasleen Kaur, her father, Jasdeep Singh, and uncle Amandeep Singh on Monday.Authorities said they were taken by a convicted robber who tried to kill himself a day after the kidnappings.
Did the family know the suspect? Investigators have not found a link between the suspect and the family to show they knew each other before the kidnapping. Warnke said that while detectives had not established a clear motive or determined whether the suspect worked with any accomplices.
In other news â€¦Ukrainian national guards fire a howitzer towards Russian troops in Kharkiv. Photograph: Vyacheslav Madiyevskyy/Reuters
The Russian president, Vladimir Putin, has appeared to concede the severity of the Kremlinâ€™s recent military reversals in Ukraine, insisting Russia would â€œstabiliseâ€ the situation in four Ukrainian regions it illegally claimed as its own territory last week.
At least 16 women have died after a boat sank off the Greek island of Lesbos in the central Aegean Sea early today, in the second maritime disaster involving migrants in a day, the countryâ€™s coastguard said. The sunken boat was carrying about 40 people, the coastguard said.
Eric Weinberg, a  television writer and producer who worked on shows including Scrubs and Californication, has been arrested and charged with 18 counts including rape, sexual battery and false imprisonment by violence. The 61-year-old was initially arrested in July. On Tuesday, he was arrested again.
A ruling by a  appeals court has again thrown into question the future of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (Daca) program, which prevents the deportation of hundreds of thousands of immigrants brought into the United States as children.
Stat of the day: FBI records slight increase in 2021 homicides â€“ but data is incompleteThe FBI estimates that the number of murders increased from 22,000 in 2020 to 22,900 in 2021. Photograph: Apu Gomes/AFP/Getty ImagesThe FBIâ€™s annual crime data released yesterday suggested a slight increase in homicides in the US in 2021, but officials warned that the statistics were incomplete and excluded some major cities due to a new data tracking system. The agency said homicides increased by 4.3% in 2021, following a nearly 30% surge in homicides in 2020, which marked the largest single-year increase since the FBI began keeping count in the 1960s. But the murder rate still remained below the historic highs of 1991. The FBI estimates that the number of murders increased from 22,000 in 2020 to 22,900 in 2021.Donâ€™t miss this: can brown noise really help you concentrate?Brown noise is all the rage. Illustration: Adam Higton/The GuardianThereâ€™s a new buzz on TikTok â€“ well, not a buzz exactly. Itâ€™s more of a hum, maybe waves crashing, a purring fan or steady, heavy rain. To me, it sounds like an empty airplane, cruising peacefully at altitude. Itâ€™s brown noise, a close cousin of the better-known white noise, and TikTok users, particularly the platformâ€™s ADHD community, are all over it: there are 85.3m views for the #brownnoise hashtag. It has fans beyond those with ADHD, including the author Zadie Smith. â€œI listen to brown noise â€¦ day and night,â€ she told a Penguin podcast. â€œI live in this denuded soundscape.â€â€¦ or this: People of color have been shut out of the climate debate. Social justice is the key to a greener worldClimate activist Vanessa Nakate marches through central Stockholm with other campaigners during a protest organized by Fridays for Future. Photograph: Jonas Gratzer/Getty Imagesâ€œWhile researching a TV program in the early 1990s, I asked a staff member of a large international environmental organisation if she felt her employees reflected multicultural Britain,â€ writes Julian Agyeman. â€œShe replied calmly: â€˜Equity is not an issue for us. Weâ€™re here to save the world.â€™ While the concept of intersectionality was new at the time, the deep rupture between environmental activism on the one hand and the need for an equity framing on the other was widespread among activists and policymakers.â€Climate check: Hurricane Ian â€˜ends discussionâ€™ on climate crisis, Biden says on Florida visitJoe Biden with Ron DeSantis in Fort Myers Beach yesterday. Photograph: Evelyn Hockstein/ReutersJoe Biden has urged action to tackle the climate crisis after surveying by helicopter the devastation wrought in Florida by Hurricane Ian, one of the fiercest storms in American history. Pointing out the rise in the number of wildfires in the west and that many reservoirs were nearly empty and the Colorado River looks more like a stream, he said: â€œThereâ€™s a lot going on, and I think the one thing this has finally ended is a discussion about whether or not thereâ€™s climate change, and [that] we should do something about it.â€Last Thing: Why did Liz Truss wear the same outfit as a fictional fascist?Who wore it better: Thompson (right) or Truss? Composite: Stefan Rousseau/PA and Guy FarrowBritainâ€™s beleaguered new prime minister, Liz Truss, delivered her first speech in the role at the Conservative party conference wearing a dress that appeared identical to that of a fictional tyrannical female dictator. The red dress worn by Truss is very much like the one worn by Emma Thompson for her portrayal of Vivienne Rook in the dystopian science fiction miniseries Years and Years. Truss had another run-in with pop culture, angering the 1990s band M People by walking on stage to their hit song Moving on Up. The bandâ€™s founder, Mike Pickering, said they were â€œlividâ€.Sign upSign up for the US morning briefingFirst Thing is delivered to thousands of inboxes every weekday. If youâ€™re not already signed up, subscribe now.Get in touchIf you have any questions or comments about any of our newsletters please email newsletters@theguardian.com

text: A United Nations body has agreed to a long-term aspirational goal for aviation of net-zero emissions by 2050, despite challenges from China and Russia, as countries aligned overwhelmingly with airlines amid pressure to curb pollution from flights.Nevertheless, environmentalists criticised the non-binding nature of the agreement as toothless.The decision, described as a compromise by several European countries who wanted a more ambitious target, was met with applause by members at the 193-nation International Civil Aviation Organizationâ€™s (ICAO) assembly, held every three years.China, backed by Russia and Eritrea, questioned the feasibility of the goal without more evidence, and argued developed countries must provide financial support to developing nations who are still growing their aviation markets.An ICAO preparatory meeting in July had laid the groundwork for the non-binding target, after years of talks.Google accused of airbrushing carbon emissions in flight search resultsRead moreAirlines last year adopted a goal of net-zero emissions by 2050 in a de facto dress rehearsal that drew reservations from Chinese carriers, reflecting Beijingâ€™s more cautious stance on multilateral action.Airlines pushed for global action to avoid countries imposing different rules and fees to curb emissions.â€œWhile the agreement is not perfect, it builds upon the notable progress we have made in recent decades and will prevent a patchwork of global measures,â€ said US airline trade group Airlines for America.The assembly also approved changes to the baseline of ICAOâ€™s flagship aviation emissions agreement known as Corsia.ICAO cannot impose rules but its decisions influence national policies. Officials hope a global target set through ICAO will go beyond industry announcements to boost supplies of new sustainable aviation fuel and encourage private investment.â€œPolicymakers must send the demand signal,â€ said Nancy Young, chief sustainability officer for sustainable fuel company Alder Fuels.Sign up to Down to EarthFree weekly newsletterThe planet's most important stories. Get all the week's environment news - the good, the bad and the essentialPrivacy Notice: Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see our Privacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Countries and regions are taking steps to boost sustainable fuel use, with Europe calling for clean fuel mandates under its â€œFit for 55â€ package.Dan Rutherford, aviation director of the US-based International Council on Clean Transportation (ICCT), said richer countries would especially need to curb their emissions since developing countries were still growing their markets. â€œTo build room for poorer countries to grow their aviation sectors, richer countries will need to peak emissions even faster,â€ he said.Still, aviation is expected to remain in the crosshairs of climate groups who see the exercise as a smokescreen.Jo Dardenne, aviation director at Brussels-based group Transport and Environment, said the goal was better than no goal, but decried the lack of a plan to achieve the target. â€œItâ€™s a goal without teeth,â€ she said.

title: UN body reaches long-term aviation climate goal of net zero by 2050

text: An extremely rare â€œfancy vivid pinkâ€ diamond has sold for 453m Hong Kong dollars (Â£52m) â€“ more than double its estimated price â€“ and set a world record for the highest price per carat for a diamond sold at auction.The 11.15-carat Williamson Pink Star diamond, which is named after another pink diamond given to Queen Elizabeth II as a wedding gift, was sold to an undisclosed buyer at auction by Sothebyâ€™s Hong Kong on Friday.Tobias Kormind, the managing director of London jewellery shop 77 Diamonds, said the stoneâ€™s link to the late monarch is likely to have helped elevate its value.â€œThis is an astounding result, proving the resilience of top diamonds in a shaky economy,â€ he said. â€œWhen you consider an alluring link to Queen Elizabeth, the rising prices for pink diamonds thanks to their increasing rarity, and the backdrop of an unstable global economy.â€œSome of the worldâ€™s highest quality diamonds have seen prices double over the last 10 years.â€The Williamson Pink Star is one of only two internally flawless â€˜fancy vivid pinkâ€™ diamonds over 10 carats to appear at auction. Photograph: Tristan Fewings/Getty Images for Sothebyâ€™sThe cushion-shaped diamond is named after two other large pink diamonds: the 59.60-carat, mixed-cut, oval Pink Star diamond that sold at auction in 2017 for $71.2m (then Â£57m), and the Williamson stone, a 23.60-carat diamond given to the Queen by the Canadian geologist and ardent royalist John Thoburn Williamson in 1947.Mounted as a floral brooch designed by Frederick Mew, of Cartier, in 1953, the Williamson is said to have been a favourite of the late Queen, who wore it on many occasions during her reign, including the silver jubilee.Williamson owned the Mwadui mine in Tanzania where the Williamson stone and the Pink Star were discovered.Wenhao Yu, the chair of jewellery and watches at Sothebyâ€™s Asia, said: â€œThe discovery of a gem-quality pink diamond of any size is an extremely rare occurrence, something that â€“ with the recent closure of the Argyle mine â€“ seemed, until recently, highly improbable.â€Argyle, a Rio Tinto-owned diamond mine in the remote north of Western Australia, was closed in 2020 after 37 years of operation, during which it produced more than 865m carats of rough diamonds.Sign up to Business TodayFree daily newsletterGet set for the working day â€“ we'll point you to the all the business news and analysis you need every morningPrivacy Notice: Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see our Privacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Pink diamonds are particularly rare among coloured diamonds and no one knows exactly how they become pink geologically.â€œWhile nitrogen and boron are responsible for the vivid hues of yellow and blue diamonds respectively, there is no evidence that pink diamonds receive their colour from trace elements,â€ Sothebyâ€™s said.â€œRather, the crystal structure of the stone selectively absorbs light as a result of an idiosyncratic lattice defect, which results in an unusual arrangement of atoms in the crystal. These happy anomalies occasionally cause pink graining in the diamond crystal â€“ a perfectly brilliant display of imperfection.â€

text: It seems like a normal day in Mubende, central Uganda. Shops remain open, children are at school and public gatherings are allowed, provided people remain socially distant.The ambulances that whisk past every few hours and the health workers who wash themselves meticulously before they return home are the only indications that it is not business as usual in the densely populated mining district, which is struggling to contain an outbreak of Ebola.Twenty-nine people, including four health workers, have died since the outbreak was declared in the district on 20 September, the World Health Organization (WHO) confirmed on Wednesday.Among them was Mohammed Ali, a 37-year-old Tanzanian doctor who was working at Mubende hospital and had operated on a patient who later tested positive for the virus. Six more health workers have been infected, bringing the total number of reported cases to 63 across five sub-counties.â€œWe are scared but there is nothing we can do,â€ said Kesande Pamela, who runs a shop in Mubende town centre. â€œI must keep my shop open and make money. We have information and we are trying to keep safe. We are hoping for the best.â€On Wednesday, Yoweri Museveni, the countryâ€™s president, told Ugandans that the outbreak was under control. â€œThe government has the capacity to control this outbreak as we have done before. Therefore, there is no need for anxiety, panic, restriction of movement or unnecessary closure of public places,â€ he said in a televised address.However, Dr Christopher Mambula, programme manager for MÃ©decins Sans FrontiÃ¨res (MSF) in Uganda, said the situation was â€œvery seriousâ€. Cases were rising daily and it was still unclear how widely the virus had spread, he said, adding that the lack of a vaccine to treat the strain of Ebola responsible for the outbreak â€“ the Sudan virus â€“ was a concern.Vaccines used to successfully curb recent Ebola outbreaks in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) are not effective against the Sudan virus. The WHO said several vaccines were in various stages of development, two of which could begin clinical trials in Uganda in the coming weeks.â€œIn terms of the contacts and the spread, if you have spread in five [regions], or more than one place, it begs the question what is the chain of transmission between those different cases, is it one person who went on to contaminate other people or was it that there was something like a super-spreader event, like a funeral, where not just one person got contaminated but several,â€ said Mambula.â€œUntil we get the indication otherwise, I would say this is very serious,â€ he said. â€œThe reality is especially when you look at the incubation period, which is generally up to three weeks, itâ€™s possible to go a week without seeing a case then suddenly 50 cases come up in one day.â€œItâ€™s still very early days and it looks like itâ€™s increasing and not decreasing. As of today, thereâ€™s nothing to say itâ€™s in control.â€Ghana reports first cases of deadly Ebola-like Marburg virusRead moreHealth workers have also said they are concerned the disease could spread to refugee camps. Mubende, about three hoursâ€™ drive from the capital, Kampala, lies along a highway to DRC. Along this route are several refugee settlements, housing at least 200,000 of Ugandaâ€™s 1.5 million refugees.The WHO has given $2m from its emergency fund and is sending â€œadditional specialists, supplies, and resourcesâ€ to help Ugandaâ€™s Ministry of Health contain the virus, which is spread through contact with blood and body fluids. MSF has established a treatment unit in Mubende hospital and plans to open another in nearby Madudu sub-county, the centre of the outbreak.The health minister, Jane Ruth Aceng, called this week for more international support. â€œThe efforts made so far are important but need to be intensified if we are to end this epidemic today,â€ she said. â€œI count on all of you to mobilise more resources in your respective capacities to end the Ebola pandemic in our country.â€The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention, part of the African Union, said Uganda would host a ministerial meeting next week with neighbouring states and other African countries that had experienced Ebola outbreaks to explore ways of managing them.This is the first outbreak of the Sudan strain of Ebola in Uganda since 2012. The country is still battling the after-effects of the Covid pandemic, which saw schools close for nearly two years.
author: [{'name': 'Harriet Nankya in Kampala and Kaamil Ahmed'}]
title: Health workers among dead in Ugandan Ebola outbreak

text: The United States has accused Russian mercenaries of exploiting natural resources in Central African Republic, Mali, Sudan and elsewhere to help fund Moscowâ€™s war in Ukraine, a charge Russia rejected as â€œanti-Russian rageâ€.The US ambassador to the United Nations, Linda Thomas-Greenfield, said the Wagner Group of mercenaries are exploiting natural resources and â€œthese ill-gotten gains are used to fund Moscowâ€™s war machine in Africa, the Middle East and Ukraineâ€.â€œMake no mistake: people across Africa are paying a heavy price for the Wagner Groupâ€™s exploitative practices and human rights violations,â€ Thomas-Greenfield told a UN security council meeting on the financing of armed groups through illicit trafficking of natural resources in Africa.Wagner, staffed by veterans of the Russian armed forces, has fought in Libya, Syria, Central African Republic, Mali and other countries. It was founded in 2014 after Russia annexed Ukraineâ€™s Crimea peninsula and started supporting pro-Russia separatists in Ukraineâ€™s eastern Donbas region.The Russian ambassador to the UN, Vassily Nebenzia,said he regretted that Thomas-Greenfield raised the issue of â€œRussian support to African partnersâ€.â€œThis exposes their real plans and aims â€“ what they really need from African countries,â€ said Nebenzia, without elaborating.Russiaâ€™s February invasion of Ukraine came at a time of heightened rivalry between the west, China and Russia over Africaâ€™s natural resources, trade and security ties. Some states worry about being squeezed in the middle of an intense geopolitical rivalry.Russia rallies support in Africa as doubt cast on Ukraine grain deal Read moreRussia has been trying to chip away at its international isolation after nearly three-quarters of the General Assembly voted to reprimand Moscow and demand it withdraw its troops within a week of its 24 February invasion of neighbouring Ukraine.Next week, the 193-member General Assembly willvote on whether to condemn Moscowâ€™s annexationof four partly occupied regions in Ukraine after staging what it called referendums.

title: Russian mercenaries â€˜exploiting Africa to fund war in Ukraineâ€™

text: African climate activists from some of the countries most affected by global heating say they are struggling to get access to the UN climate talks in Egypt in November.Cop27, which has been termed â€œthe African Copâ€, threatens to take place without African activists advocating for communities devastated by drought, floods and fossil fuel projects in the negotiations when life-or-death decisions about climate finance will be made.The Guardian view on Cop27: climate justice must take centre stage | EditorialRead moreAfrica is the continent most affected by the climate breakdown. So far this year, hundreds of people have died from floods and landslides in Nigeria and Uganda while as many as 37 million face starvation after four consecutive droughts in the greater Horn of Africa. Itâ€™s also the continent which has contributed least to the climate crisis.Yet just over 20% of grassroots activists have secured accreditation, and only a handful have funding to cover expenses such as travel, accommodation and visas, according to a coalition of African youth climate leaders. With just over a month to go before negotiations open and affordable hotels in short supply, the coalition, which includes the youth groups Fridays for Futures and Riseup in Africa, conducted the survey to review progress.Despite reaching out to hundreds of non-profits and foundations for help securing badges â€“ which are required for people to enter the negotiating rooms â€“ not a single young activist from countries including Egypt, Burundi, the Democratic Republic of Congo, Mali, Tanzania, Morocco, Chad, South Africa, Benin and Somalia has so far secured a place at Cop27.Africa has the youngest population in the world, with 70% of sub-Saharan Africans under the age of 30.â€œI have a voice, I want the privilege to speak,â€ said Goodness Dickson, 29, from Abuja, Nigeria, who carried out the survey. â€œDespite Egypt being called an African Cop, weâ€™re having a very serious challenge and many countries most affected by the climate crisis wonâ€™t be represented.â€According to Dickson, organisations which promised youth leaders conference badges now say they did not receive enough of them to share. Others simply havenâ€™t responded.â€œEveryone I reached out to said there are no more slots. Iâ€™ve been invited to speak at three different events and they all say they have no funding for travel â€¦ I gave up,â€ said Jennifer Olachi Uchendu, founder of the Nigerian sustainability organisation SustyVibes.â€œThis is the African Cop, they say, but it seems to be even worse to access â€¦ and voices like mine who advocate for climate justice, loss and damage finance may be seen as threats. Is there really a point to all of this? The multiple conversations?â€ added Uchendu, who also runs a project supporting Africans suffering from climate anxiety.Activists engage in a protest at last yearâ€™s Cop26 in Glasgow, Scotland. Photograph: Alastair Grant/APLast year at Cop26 in Glasgow, Uchendu was among the few African activists able to attend due to similar challenges with accreditation, funding and Covid vaccinations â€“ which at the time were available to less than 5% of people across the African continent. Dickson was stopped from boarding his flight as he was not fully vaccinated.In the end, concrete pledges on loss and damage for developing nations which have contributed least to global heating but are affected most by it were once again shelved at the behest of rich polluting nations. The 54 countries in Africa combined account for 15% of the worldâ€™s population but contribute less than 4% of global greenhouse emissions â€“ in contrast to 23% by China, 19% by the US and 13% from the European Union.Egypt, which holds the presidency for Cop27, has boasted that the conference in Sharm el-Sheikh is on track to be one of the most attended with more than 35,000 people registered to take part.But registration is not accreditation â€“ the all-important badge gives access to the main events and negotiation areas, which are where decisions on climate financing, agriculture, water scarcity and biodiversity are discussed. Even then, only a handful of civil society representatives are permitted inside each meeting room, with no guarantee of addressing the country delegates and negotiators.Those who have secured badges still face multiple challenges. Egyptâ€™s confusing visa system requires people from dozens of African and Asian countries to apply for pre-approval, with no exceptions for Cop27 participants, a process that can take weeks.Mana Omar, 27, is a climate justice activist in Kenyaâ€™s arid Kajiado county where pastoral Indigenous communities have been extremely hard hit by the prolonged drought. Omar got her badge through UN Women, but is struggling to finance the trip. â€œItâ€™s still 50:50,â€ she said. â€œItâ€™s very, very hard to get the funding and the hotel costs are too high.â€œI need to be there to advocate for communities like mine to be prioritised in loss and damage finance. We are at the frontline of the climate crisis, facing the risk of extinction,â€ said Omar, founder and CEO of Spring of the Arid and Semi-Arid Lands and member of Fridays for Future.Cop27 host Egypt warns UK not to backtrack from climate agendaRead moreTravel and accommodation costs are extortionate, with no sanctions for price gouging or cancellations â€“ leaving many non-profits that booked rooms early scrambling to find alternatives, according to Dharini Parthasarathy, global communications lead for the Climate Action Network. â€œItâ€™s a free-for-all. The logistics are serious barriers.â€Climate journalism, open to allAmid pressure from civil society groups, Egyptian authorities recently promised to subsidise 400 rooms for young people, though few details are available. Egypt, where water scarcity is approaching crisis levels, also announced Coca-Cola as its sponsor, despite the companyâ€™s large water guzzling and pollution footprint across the continent.â€œIndigenous lives matter. If Coca-Cola is going, our voices have to be heard. I have to get there,â€ said Ina-Maria Shikongo, 43, a climate activist and artist from Namibia looking for funding. â€œWe have to be there pushing political leaders for loss and damage financing and a fossil fuels non-proliferation treaty.â€After months of hard work and hundreds of emails, Grace Kimaru, 23, founder of the conservation group Foster Green in Nairobi, Kenya, secured a badge and funding. â€œIt was a struggle, but I will be at Cop27 and try my level best to be heard. African activists and environmentalists should be at the table and taken seriously. Young people have to be involved to safeguard the future and the planet. I hope this will be the Cop of action when pledges are implemented, not more blah blah blah.â€
author: [{'name': 'Nina Lakhani Climate justice reporter'}]
title: â€˜I have a voiceâ€™: African activists struggle to attend UN climate talks in Egypt

text: Haitiâ€™s government has authorized the prime minister, Ariel Henry, to ask the international community for a â€œspecialized armed forceâ€ to address a crisis caused by a blockade of the countryâ€™s main fuel port that has led to crippling shortages, according to a decree circulating on Friday.Crisis-hit Haiti braces for new cholera outbreak as gangs hamper relief effortsRead moreHaiti has ground to a halt since a coalition of gangs blocked the Varreux fuel terminal last month. The lack of gas and diesel has crippled transportation and forced businesses and hospitals to halt operations.It has also led to a shortage of bottled water, just as the country confirmed a new outbreak of cholera, the spread of which is controlled through hygiene and clean water.The decree allows Henry to â€œsolicit and obtain from Haitiâ€™s international partners effective support through immediate deployment of a specialized armed force to stop ... the insecurity resulting from the joint actions of armed gangs and their sponsorsâ€.It was not immediately evident which countries would receive such a request.Nor was it clear if the request would mean the activation of United Nations peacekeeping troops, whose mission ended five years ago after a troubled 11 years in Haiti.The international body sent thousands of soldiers and police officers to restore order after a rebellion toppled President Jean-Bertrand Aristide in 2004.In 2017, the UN withdrew military personnel and said it would focus more on the justice system and the Haitian police.But Haitiâ€™s national police have struggled to control gangs with its limited resources and chronic understaffing, with only some 12,800 active officers for a country of more than 11 million people.The gangs have only grown more powerful since the July 2021 assassination of President Jovenel MoÃ¯se.Critics question the extent to which the United Nations achieved its objectives of helping Haiti improve political stability and strengthen its rule of law institutions.â€˜They have no fear and no mercyâ€™: gang rule engulfs Haitian capitalRead moreMany Haitians have strongly rejected the idea of another international intervention, noting that UN peacekeepers were accused of sexual assault and sparked a cholera epidemic more than a decade ago that killed thousands.â€œI donâ€™t think Haiti needs another intervention,â€ said Mathias Pierre, Haitiâ€™s former elections minister. â€œWe have been through so many, and nothing has been solved â€¦ If we donâ€™t do it as Haitians, 10 years forward, weâ€™re going to be in the same situation again.â€He called on the US government to help reduce the amount of ammunition and guns flowing to Haiti, and to further equip police officers so they have more weapons and the ability to run intelligence on gangs.He also worried about the situation that an international security force would encounter.â€œItâ€™s not an army theyâ€™re facing,â€ he said. â€œTheyâ€™re facing gangs located in poor areas and using the population as shields to protect themselves.â€The United Nations has not received an official request from the Haitian government, the UN spokesman Stephane Dujarric said on Friday.â€œThat being said, we remain extremely concerned about the security situation in Haiti, the impact itâ€™s having on the Haitian people, on our ability to do our work, especially in the humanitarian sphere,â€ Dujarric told reporters.

title: Haiti government prepares to ask for â€˜specialized armed forceâ€™ from abroad

text: A New York City man faces up to 20 years in prison for allegedly attempting to smuggle three large snakes across the US-Canada border â€“ in his pants.Queens resident Calvin Bautista, 36, is accused of hiding three Burmese pythons while on a bus crossing into the US at the Champlain port of entry in New York state on 15 July 2018, the Associated Press reported.â€˜Out of a horror movieâ€™: Pennsylvania officer shoots snake around manâ€™s neckRead moreBautista was arraigned this week in court in Albany, the New York state capital.He faces federal smuggling charges, as importing Burmese pythons is regulated by an international treaty and federal law.Bringing the pythons into the US from another country requires permits under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, which Bautista did not have, the Fort-Worth Star Telegram reported.Bautista was released in the lead-up to his trial, the Department of Justice said.If convicted, he faces a maximum of 20 years in prison, a $250,000 fine and three years of supervised release.The case is being investigated by the US Fish and Wildlife Service and US Customs and Border Protection.Burmese pythons are one of the largest species of snakes, growing up to 16ft. While the pythons are not considered at risk of extinction, they are considered a vulnerable species in Asia and an invasive species in Florida.
author: [{'name': 'Gloria Oladipo in New York'}]
title: Trouser snakes: US man accused of smuggling three reptiles in his pants

text: Amazon deforestation has soared ahead of Brazilâ€™s environmentally vital presidential election, with an area almost the size of Greater London lost last month alone.Government satellites show a 1,455-sq km area of rainforest was destroyed in September, as environmental criminals raced to wreck the region before a possible change of president could bring Jair Bolsonaroâ€™s era of destruction to an end.â€˜Last-chance saloonâ€™: race to wreck the Amazon as prospect of Bolsonaro defeat loomsRead moreThe Climate Observatory watchdog said that figure was up 47.7% compared with last September and on a par with the destruction wrought in September 2019, the first year of Bolsonaroâ€™s far-right administration. August saw a 81% rise in deforestation.The number of Amazon fires rose 147% compared with September 2021, with more than 41,000 blazes detected by satellites.â€œThis is a very dangerous moment,â€ warned Marcio Astrini, the Climate Observatoryâ€™s chief executive. â€œThe Bolsonaro government is a forest-destroying machine.â€Astrini said Fridayâ€™s grim figures exposed how criminal syndicates of illegal loggers and ranchers were scrambling to clear the rainforest before Bolsonaro could be voted out of power in the second round of Brazilâ€™s presidential election on 30 October. Bolsonaro lost Sundayâ€™s first round to his leftist rival, the former president Luiz InÃ¡cio Lula da Silva, but received more votes than forecast by polls.â€œThey can see that their president could lose the election so theyâ€™re taking advantage of this final stretch of Bolsonaro to tear down everything they possibly can,â€ Astrini said.Why did the Brazil election pollsters get Bolsonaroâ€™s vote so wrong?Read moreDeforestation has soared under Bolsonaro, a pro-development nationalist who has slashed environmental regulations, debilitated the government agencies tasked with protecting the Amazon and incentivized the invasion of Indigenous lands.More than 2bn trees have been killed over the last four years, the Amazon newsletter SumaÃºma reported last month, as well as up to 3.8 million monkeys and 89.9 million birds which may have been killed, injured or otherwise affected.Violence against Indigenous communities and environmentalists has also increased, a reality laid bare by the murders of Guardian contributor Dom Phillips and the Brazilian activist Bruno Pereira in June.Astrini said Bolsonaroâ€™s defeat was essential to efforts to slow such destruction and protect the global climate, given the Amazonâ€™s crucial role as a carbon sink. â€If [this government] is given another four years the Amazonâ€™s future will be uncertain,â€ he said, noting that 2022 had already seen 4% more deforestation than 2021 â€“ and there were still three months to go.05:57How the Amazon has started to heat the planet â€“ videoâ€œWhatâ€™s at stake here is either us continuing to have any hope that the Amazon can be kept from collapsing â€“ or definitively surrendering it to environmental criminals,â€ Astrini said.Lula, who managed to reduce Amazon destruction during his 2003-2010 administration, has vowed to revive protection efforts, stamp out illegal gold-mining and create a ministry for native peoples, if elected.In August, the veteran leftist told foreign journalists he would make the climate crisis â€œan absolute priorityâ€ although critics say Lula was far from an environmental saint given his construction of the Belo Monte mega-dam.Reports in the Brazilian media suggest that if he beats Bolsonaro, Lula will call an immediate climate summit in an effort to restore Brazilâ€™s international credibility, obliterated, like the Amazon, during Bolsonaroâ€™s four years in office.

title: Amazon loses London-sized area of rainforest in a month with Bolsonaroâ€™s reign under threat

text: A forest fire that tore through part of Easter Island has charred some of its monumental carved stone figures, known as moai, authorities have said.The blaze reportedly swept through the Rapa Nui national park, 3,500km (2,175 miles) off the west coast of Chile, causing â€œirreparableâ€ damage to the archaeological site.â€œMore than 100 hectares (247 acres) were affected in the Rano Raraku sector which includes the wetland and moai sector,â€ the national park said in a statement on its official Facebook page on Thursday.Carolina Perez, cultural heritage undersecretary, said the island - which lies 3,500km (2,175 miles) off the west coast of Chile - had been razed by flames since Monday.Rapa Nui has more than 1,000 stone statues â€“ giant heads that are believed to have first been carved in the 13th century by the islandâ€™s original inhabitants. The area around the Rano Raraku volcano, a Unesco world heritage site, was reportedly the most affected.An estimated several hundred moai are in that area, as well as in the quarry where the stone used to carve the sculptures is extracted.The area around the Rano Raraku volcano, a Unesco world heritage site, was reportedly the most affected. Photograph: Rapanui Municipality/AFP/Getty ImagesAriki Tepano, director of the Maâ€™u Henua community in charge of the management and maintenance of the park, described the damage as â€œirreparableâ€.â€œThe moai are totally charred and you can see the effect of the fire upon them,â€ he said.Easter Island mayor, Pedro Edmunds Paoa, said he believed the fire was â€œnot an accident,â€ telling local broadcaster Radio Pauta that â€œall the fires on Rapa Nui are caused by human beings.â€â€œThe damage caused by the fire canâ€™t be undone,â€ Edmunds Paoa added. â€œThe cracking of an original and emblematic stone cannot be recovered, no matter how many millions of euros or dollars are put into it.â€Easter Island statues: mystery behind their location revealedRead moreThe park said a â€œshortage of volunteersâ€ hindered the ability of officials to get the fire under control. The total damage to the site has yet to be assessed.The fire comes just three months after the island was reopened to tourism on 5 August, after two years of closure due to Covid-19.Smoke seen in a valley of the Rapa Nui national park in Easter Island, Chile, on 6 October. Photograph: Rapanui Municipality/AFP/Getty ImagesBefore the pandemic, Easter Island â€“ where the main livelihood is tourism â€“ received 160,000 visitors a year, on two daily flights.But with the arrival of Covid-19 in Chile, tourist activity was completely suspended.The island was long inhabited by Polynesian people, before Chile annexed it in 1888. It is thought the monuments represent the living ancestors of Easter Islandâ€™s Polynesian people and were once linked to ritual activity, forming a focal point for communities.

title: Easter Island fire causes â€˜irreparableâ€™ damage to famous moai statues

text: Canadian police have concluded that Myles Sanderson, who led officers on a multi-day manhunt after a mass stabbing last month, was responsible for all 11 deaths â€“ including that of his brother.Officers initially named Sandersonâ€™s brother Damien as a suspect in the stabbings in James Smith Cree Nation and the nearby town of Weldon, Saskatchewan.But on Tuesday the commanding officer of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police in the province told reporters they had concluded Damien was a victim who played no part in the killings. â€œMyles Sanderson committed all of the homicides alone,â€ said Assistant Commissioner Rhonda Blackmore.After his deadly rampage, in which 18 people were also injured on 4 September, Myles Sanderson evaded an intensive search for four days until he was captured by police following a high-speed chase near the city of Saskatoon.Sanderson then went into what police described as â€œmedical distressâ€ and died in custody soon after.Damien Sanderson was initially charged with one count of first-degree murder, one count of attempted murder and one count of breaking and entering in connection to the mass stabbing.Police said on Thursday all charges had been withdrawn by the Crown following the deaths of Myles and Damien, according to RCMP.Damienâ€™s body was found in a grassy area on James Smith Cree Nation on 5 September. Police said at the time they did not believe his wounds were self-inflicted.â€œThe Saskatchewan RCMP believes it is important to clarify Damienâ€™s involvement in the sequence of these events to demonstrate our continued commitment to transparency to the victims and the families of those affected and to the public,â€ said Blackmore.Mountiesâ€™ missteps creating crisis of confidence in Canadaâ€™s policeRead moreAlso on Thursday the Parole Board of Canada and Correctional Service of Canada announced they would create a joint board to investigate Myles Sandersonâ€™s release from federal custody.Sanderson, who was serving a nearly five-year sentence for assault, robbery, mischief and uttering threats, and had a long history of violence, was granted statutory release in August 2021.After failing to remain in contact with his parole officer, Crime Stoppers issued an alert in May that Sanderson was â€œunlawfully at largeâ€.The newly created board will investigate whether policies and protocols were correctly followed during Sandersonâ€™s release from federal custody and will make recommendations or suggest corrective measures if necessary.
author: [{'name': 'Leyland Cecco in Toronto'}]
title: Canada mass stabbing suspectâ€™s brother was victim not accomplice, police say

text: Justin Trudeau has warned Canadaâ€™s ice hockey governing body that it has â€œlost the confidenceâ€ of Canadians and could be easily replaced by a new organization, amid growing outcry about its handling of a string of sexual assault allegations.The prime ministerâ€™s comments come as a wave of major companies publicly pulled support for the embattled organization on Thursday.In a country where hockey remains one of the most beloved sports, the unprecedented rebuke from some of Canadaâ€™s most well-known brands has only deepened the sense of a national scandal.Earlier this year, Hockey Canada executives told a parliamentary committee that the organization had secretly paid nearly C$9m (US$6.6m) to 21 complainants of sexual misconduct.Reporting by national media outlets later revealed that young players across the country had unknowingly funded most of those payments through their registration fees to the organization.According to reporting by the Globe and Mail, Hockey Canada also failed to disclose to parliament the existence of a second secret fund to pay for legal efforts to fend off sexual assault claims.Police in Halifax, Nova Scotia, and London, Ontario, have reopened investigations into allegations of sexual assaults by players at Hockey Canada-sanctioned events. But the organisation has refused to take action against senior executives.â€œIt is inconceivable that folks at Hockey Canada continue to dig in. Itâ€™s not like thereâ€™s something extraordinarily special about the people at Hockey Canada that means they are the only people in the country that can run an organization like this,â€ Trudeau told reporters before a cabinet meeting on Thursday.â€œThey need to realize that if we have to create an organization, get rid of Hockey Canada and create an organization called â€˜Canada Hockeyâ€™ instead, people will look at doing that.â€On Thursday, Canadian Tire, one of the countryâ€™s largest retailers, became the first sponsor to permanently sever its financial support for the organization.â€œIn our view, Hockey Canada continues to resist meaningful change and we can no longer confidently move forward together,â€ Jane Shaw, the companyâ€™s senior vice-president of communications, wrote in a statement, adding the company would instead fund â€œhockey-related organizations that better align with our valuesâ€ including a group that campaigns about abuse and harassment in sports.â€œWe are committed to supporting hockey and sport that is inclusive and safe for all Canadians,â€ she said.Other large companies, including Tim Hortons and telecoms giant Telus, said they would suspend sponsorship of Hockey Canada menâ€™s events for the 2022-23 season, including the World Junior championship tournament.â€œWeâ€™ve communicated to Hockey Canada on many occasions that the organization needs to take strong and definitive action before it can regain the faith and trust of Canadians,â€ Michael Oliveira, Tim Hortons director of communications, wrote in a statement. â€œWeâ€™re deeply disappointed in the lack of progress that Hockey Canada has made to date.â€Tim Hortons said it would continue to support both the womenâ€™s and para hockey programs.Despite mounting pressure on the organization, the interim board chair, Andrea Skinner, testified at a parliamentary hearing this week that Hockey Canada had an â€œexcellent reputationâ€ and suggested media reports were unfairly targeting â€œhockey as a centrepiece for toxic cultureâ€.Canadaâ€™s federal sports minister, Pascale St-Onge, has said mass resignations of the executives would help Hockey Canada regain public trust â€“ something Skinner ruled out.â€œParents across the country are losing faith or have lost faith in Hockey Canada. Certainly, politicians here in Ottawa have lost faith in Hockey Canada,â€ Trudeau said on Wednesday, adding that the organizationâ€™s attitude to the scandal â€œboggles the mindâ€.
author: [{'name': 'Leyland Cecco in Toronto'}]
title: Trudeau intervenes as sexual abuse scandal rocks Canadaâ€™s ice hockey body

text: Toy trucks, baby bottles and flowers were left beside the coffins of victims of the mass killing that took place at a nursery school in north-eastern Thailand, as preparations for funeral ceremonies began on Saturday.Inside wat Rat Samakee, a temple in Uthai Sawan where most of the child victims were taken, families sat beside their loved onesâ€™ remains. A mother held on to her sonâ€™s red blanket as she stared ahead. Another woman hugged her loved oneâ€™s photo tightly.Some families stayed overnight to ensure candles and incense they had placed next to their loved oneâ€™s remains did not go out. It was a tradition, local people said, to prevent the soul from straying and becoming lost.Next to each coffin, photographs showed young toddlers smiling and posing; one boy sat with a puppy on his lap, another was pictured drawing in her book.In one photo, a four-year-old boy posed in a football shirt and shorts. Beside his coffin, a toy truck and digger, a baby milk bottle, fizzy pop and sweets were left as offerings.â€˜I saw my grandsonâ€™s name and I faintedâ€™: grief engulfs town after Thailand nursery attackRead moreThirty-seven people were killed, mostly young children, when a former police officer opened fire and stabbed people in an attack that began at a preschool centre in Uthai Sawan. After the attacker left the nursery he drove his car towards and shot at bystanders, then returned home, where he shot his wife, child and himself.Nineteen of the victimsâ€™ remains were kept in wat Rat Samakee. All but one were children.The only adult victim held at the temple was a teacher. She was eight monthsâ€™ pregnant, said Pra Kru Adisai Kitjanuwat, abbott at wat Rat Samakee.Tributes are placed for the victims on Saturday at Wat Rat Samakee temple following a mass shooting in the town of Uthai Sawan. Photograph: Jorge Silva/Reutersâ€œAs the temple is the centre of the community, my role right now is to make people united,â€ he said. â€œI help them to stay united, I help them with whatever they need.â€He said he knew all of the local children, who call him Luang Taa, meaning Grandpa Monk. â€œItâ€™s an Isan tradition, they bring the kids to the temple,â€ he said with red eyes.The community had come together, despite the terrible events, he added. â€œI actually feel, in a way, that Iâ€™m proud of the people here. Even though this is such a hard time, they come together, they are united together. I know everybody is in a difficult place but they are united to get through it.â€Next to the temple, local people sat chopping papaya and mixing som tam salad for families and visitors.â€œWe came here to do whatever we can, we want to support the family,â€ said Naparat Kaesapan, who lives locally and was helping to prepare food. â€œCooking, buying ingredients, welcoming the guests â€“ because I know the families will not be in the state of mind or have the time to do this.â€They didnâ€™t want to bother the families, she said. â€œWe just say we are right here by their side, and keep going.â€Everyone is still in shock. â€œI try to not look at the news,â€ Naparat said.Funeral proceedings were expected to begin on Saturday afternoon with a bathing ceremony. Pra Kru Adisai said the coffins would remain closed throughout, due to the nature of the killings.Offerings, toys and portraits placed for the victims of Thailandâ€™s nursery attack. Photograph: Lauren DeCicca/Getty ImagesLater in the afternoon, royal water would be used in a separate ceremony. All victims have been taken under royal patronage.On Friday night, King Maha Vajiralongkorn and Queen Suthida met victims at a local hospital. In a speech, the king offered condolences to families, saying it was â€œa time of sorrowâ€ and that he felt deep sadness.â€œIf you are in difficulties, let me help and take care [of you]. I offer my condolences to you,â€ he said. â€œThere are no words that can describe the sorrow.â€He offered to support the victims, saying that he shared their sorrow.
author: [{'name': 'Rebecca Ratcliffe and Navaon Siradapuvadol in Uthai Sawan'}]
title: Thailand nursery attack: offerings amid heartbreak as families ready for victimsâ€™ funerals

text: Thailand was in a state of mourning on Friday after a gun and knife attack at a nursery left dozens dead and prompted calls for gun control and a crackdown on illicit drugs.Thirty-seven people were killed when a former police officer opened fire and stabbed children as they slept at the preschool in Uthai Sawan, a town 310 miles north-east of Bangkok on Thursday.After the attacker left the nursery he drove his car towards and shot at bystanders, then returned home where he shot his wife, child and himself.On Friday, the relatives of those killed gathered at the nursery, where they lay white roses on the buildingâ€™s entrance steps before travelling to local temples to receive their loved oneâ€™s coffins. Twenty-three children were killed in the attack.The Thai government ordered all Thai flags to be lowered to half mast while the prime minister, Prayuth Chan-ocha, visited the nursery and laid flowers outside. Afterwards, he met families of the victims and handed out compensation cheques.Police said the perpetrator was a former police officer. Photograph: Thailandâ€™s Central Investigation/AFP/ Getty ImagesOn Friday evening, King Maha Vajiralongkorn and Queen Suthida were also expected to meet victims and their families. Crowds gathered outside a local hospital to see the motorcade pass by.The attacker, identified by police as Panya Khamrab, a 34-year-old former police lieutenant colonel, was dismissed from the force in January for methamphetamine possession and was officially fired in June. He had appeared in court earlier on Thursday on a drug charge and was due to appear again on Friday.His mother told Nation TV that he was in debt and had drug addiction problems. â€œI donâ€™t know [why he did this], but he was under a lot of pressure,â€ she said.Thai media reported that autopsy results indicated he had not taken drugs in the 72 hours prior to his death. However, the mass killing has prompted calls for a tougher stance on drugs, including methamphetamine, supplies of which have grown rapidly across south-east Asia over recent years.The opposition Pheu Thai party said it is preparing to open an extraordinary session of the House of Representatives after the tragedy.00:58'He used a knife, he kept slashing': Thailand daycare attack survivor â€“ videoâ€œI blame the government for neglecting the problem of drugs that caused this tragic event,â€ said Prasert Chantararuangthong, secretary-general of Pheu Thai, the party formed of loyalists to exiled former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra, whose infamous â€œwar on drugsâ€ left 2,500 people dead.More than 1bn methamphetamine tablets were seized in east and south-east Asia in 2021 â€“ seven times higher than 10 years ago. Analysts say the cartels, whose production is centred in south-east Asiaâ€™s Golden Triangle along the borders between Thailand, Myanmar and Laos, continue despite police raids.Emergency service workers arrange coffins containing the bodies of victims. Photograph: Athit Perawongmetha/ReutersA recent UN report said that the price of tablet and crystal methamphetamine had fallen to all-time lows due to a surge in supply.According to local reports, a tablet costs 10 baht (Â£0.24) for wholesale, about the same as a bottle of water. The street price for the pills is between 20 and 25 baht.Mass shootings are rare in Thailand, though gun ownership rates are high. In 2020, a soldier killed at least 29 people and wounded 57 after opening fire in four locations, including a busy shopping mall in north-east Thailand.In Uthai Sawan, local people and grieving families struggled to come to terms with what had happened.The daycare centre sits empty a day after it was attacked. Photograph: Sakchai Lalit/APâ€œI cried until I had no more tears coming out of my eyes. They are running through my heart,â€ Seksan Sriraj, 28, told Associated Press. He lost his pregnant wife, who was due to give birth this month.â€œMy wife and my child have gone to a peaceful place. I am alive and will have to live. If I canâ€™t go on, my wife and my child will be worried about me, and they wonâ€™t be reborn in the next life,â€ he said.The attacker first opened fire outside the nursery, according to witness accounts given to local media. Teachers had tried to lock the front door to keep him out, but he shot and kicked his way into the building.In an interview with Amarin TV, Satita Boonsom, who worked at the daycare centre, said she and three other teachers climbed the centreâ€™s fence to escape and call for help. By the time she returned, the children were dead. She said one child who was covered by a blanket survived the attack, apparently because the assailant assumed he was dead.Sumate Uthathit, of Ruamjai Kupai Naklang rescue team, who recovered victims on Thursday, said the atmosphere was one of chaos. â€œWhen we entered, we saw a lot of bodies. We were shocked because we only got information about four bodies, but it was more than 20 bodies,â€ he said. â€œTheir families tried to get in. They were panicking.â€Some families stayed outside the nursery until late on Thursday evening, Thai media reported, with trained staff giving mental health support.On Friday, relatives gathered again at the nursery, many wearing black, where they were given government assistance.In the afternoon, coffins bearing the bodies of the victims were taken to local families, to be handed over to relatives. Some fainted as the small coffins were opened. Paramedics revived them with smelling salts.Politicians across the world offered their condolences, while the UN secretary general, AntÃ³nio Guterres, said he was â€œprofoundly saddened by the heinous shootingâ€.

title: Thailand in mourning after children killed in mass stabbing and shooting

text: On Friday morning, in the baking sun, grieving parents filed in a line to leave flowers outside the Uthai Sawan nursery school in northern Thailand. Women dressed in black and with heads bowed each placed a white rose on the entrance steps.A mother, standing at the side, clutched her sonâ€™s red blanket and his milk bottle, still half-full.A day before, the building was the centre of one of Thailandâ€™s most deadly mass killings. Thirty-seven people, most of them young children, were killed in the brutal attack that began at the nursery.Uthai Sawan, a rural town about 300 miles (480km) north-east of Bangkok, is, like much of Thailand, in a state of shock.At a hall next to the nursery building, relatives stunned by the events sat in rows, waiting to give their details to officials. Some wept, others leaned on one anotherâ€™s shoulders for comfort.Mourners have gathered to place white roses on the steps of the childcare centre. Photograph: Manan Vatsyayana/AFP/Getty ImagesPimpa Thana sat in the middle of the hall with her husband. Her two twin boys, Ongsa and Phupa, were killed in the attack. They were three years old. â€œThey liked to dance, they liked to listen to fairytales, they liked to play with each other,â€ she said.Her family felt numb, she said.As Thailand struggles to come to terms with the attack, there is a sense of anger as well as disbelief.Nuankanjana Sola, 49, lost her four-year-old grandson in the killing. When she heard there had been an incident on Thursday, she went to the centre immediately. â€œI rushed to check the name list, and I saw my grandsonâ€™s name and I fainted.â€He was such a lovely kid, she said, chatty and playful, and always pestering her to buy new toys.â€œIâ€™m furious that the gunman did this to the children who had no power to protect themselves. Itâ€™s such a cruel incident,â€ she says. His mother, she said, could not sleep or eat.Nearby, medical workers set up tables to offer mental health support, while monks presented families with donations and robes. The prime minister, Prayuth Chan-ocha, and other government officials also visited the nursery to leave flowers and meet families. Local people brought donations of water and food.Napaporn Horngan, 44, who lives in the town, said she came to support those who had lost loved ones. â€œEven if I stayed home I would still cry,â€ she said.Her grandson, seven, who sat beside her, went to the same nursery, she said. Most local children go there. â€œI donâ€™t know what to say. I am speechless.â€The government should crack down on the sale of methamphetamine â€“ many people are addicted, she said.Others echoed her view. Jeerand Pannaorath, 53, said his granddaughter, who is three years old, usually attends the nursery but stayed home on Thursday because she was sick.â€œI am a farmer, I grow rice and sugarcane so I donâ€™t have time to take care of her, so I drop her at the centre from 8am to 2pm, Monday to Friday,â€ he said.The centre usually looks after 70 to 80 children, according to reports, but there were fewer at the time of the attack because the term had ended for older children and heavy rain prevented some from travelling.On Thursday, Jeerand heard two loud bangs but assumed they were firecrackers. â€œWho would have imagined that it was actually gunshots? This is in the government compound,â€ he said, referring to the nursery, which is state run.When he heard there was an incident, he went to see what had happened. Outside the nursery, he saw the body of a dead child, with wounds on his head. â€œI could not stay longer. It was so sad. I felt tight in my chest. I went home.â€The availability of drugs and the lack of gun control are to blame, he said. â€œDrugs are so cheap around here. I saw people trading drugs in front of my house.â€Rabieb, a local woman, also heard the loud bang on Thursday, but, like others, assumed it was a firecracker. â€œI have never experienced anything like this. We lost one teacher who lives in our village. The feeling in the village in the morning, itâ€™s just sad.â€

title: â€˜I saw my grandsonâ€™s name and I faintedâ€™: grief engulfs town after Thailand nursery attack

text: In the 41 years of wielding the gavel at his auction house a stoneâ€™s throw from the royal chateau at Fontainebleau, Jean-Pierre Osenat had never seen anything like it.â€œThis is a crazy story,â€ he said. â€œQuite extraordinary.â€The story has cost one of the auctioneerâ€™s experts his job, after a Chinese vase he declared an ordinary decorative piece worth â‚¬2,000 (Â£1,760) at most sold for almost â‚¬8m, nearly 4,000 times the estimate.â€œThe expert made a mistake. One person alone against 300 interested Chinese buyers cannot be right,â€ Osenat said. â€œHe was working for us. He no longer works for us. It was, after all, a serious mistake.â€The extraordinary story began earlier this year when a French woman living abroad decided to sell furniture and various objects from her late motherâ€™s home in Brittany. Having entrusted Osenat with the sale, the vase â€“ which had belonged to her grandmother â€“ was packed up, dispatched to Paris and put in a â€œfurniture and works of artâ€ auction of 200 lots, none of which was valued over â‚¬8,000.Last Saturday, the vase, a Chinese tianqiuping â€“ meaning â€œheavenly globeâ€™â€ and denoting the round base and long neck â€“ stood on a display table at the Osenat auction room. The catalogue described it as: lot 36 â€œlarge tianqiuping porcelain and polychrome enamel vase in a blue-white style with globular body and long cylindrical neck, decorated with nine fierce dragons and clouds (mark under the base)â€. The 54cm by 40cm vase was noted as being in â€œgood conditionâ€.The estimated price, between â‚¬1,500 and â‚¬2,000, reflected the expertâ€™s view that it was a 20th-century decorative piece and not a rare artefact.Osenat said his suspicions this might not be the case were raised when the catalogue went online and the pre-auction exhibition was swamped with 300 to 400 interested buyers 15 days before the sale.â€œThey came with lamps and magnifying glasses to look at it. Obviously they saw something,â€ he said. â€œThere were so many registrations [to take part in the auction online] we had to stop them. At that point we understood something was happening.â€Initially, the auction house staff put the unexpected interest down to the passion of the French Chinese community for Chinaâ€™s art and history.Faced with overwhelming interest, auctioneers decided not to allow online bids and the number of buyers was limited to 30 â€“ half in the auction room the other bidding by telephone, with each required to pay a â‚¬10,000 deposit to take part.The tianqiuping-style vase attracted hundreds of interested buyers to a pre-auction exhibition. Photograph: Maison OsenatAlmost as soon as lot 36 came up frantic bidding erupted. Osenat was conducting the sale of rapidly increasing bids â€“ â‚¬100,000, â‚¬200,000, â‚¬500,000 â€“ when someone shouted â€œTwo millionâ€. By the time bids reached â‚¬5m, 10 buyers were still competing; by â‚¬7m only two remained.When the gavel was finally brought down, to applause from the room, the final bid had reached â‚¬7.7m. With fees, the anonymous Chinese buyer will pay â‚¬9.12m.Osenat said for the seller, who had moved abroad 15 years ago,the windfall came with problems and the amount would be â€œhard for them to come to terms withâ€.â€œThe vase had been in her family for generations. She said they used to put flowers in it. She had lived with it for 30 years and never imagined it was worth that much,â€ he said. â€œSheâ€™s completely unsettled. If it had sold for â‚¬150,000 that would have been something, but â‚¬7.7m is something else. Sheâ€™s terrified of being in the press and quite traumatised by it.â€The buyer bid by telephone and lives in China. It has been suggested that in addition to the vase featuring the dragon and cloud, a sought-after motif among east Asian collectors, some may have spotted a stamp of Qianlong, an 18th-century Chinese emperor, who is a sacred figure.The expert, who was sacked and has not been named, is reported to be standing by his original valuation.CÃ©dric Laborde, the director of the auction houseâ€™s Asian arts department, is still not entirely convinced the expert was wrong. â€œWe donâ€™t know whether it [the vase] is old or not or why it sold for such a price. Perhaps we will never know,â€ Laborde said.â€œThe valuation corresponded to what the expert thought. In China, copying something, like an 18th-century vase, is also an art. In this case I donâ€™t have an answer. Over the last few years there have been some surprises in auctions of Asian objects.â€Osenat, whose previous record sale was the â‚¬4.8m paid in 2007 for the sword NapolÃ©on Bonaparte carried at the Battle of Marengo in 1800, said he had faith in the auctioneerâ€™s hammer.â€œThe expert thought it was a 20th-century copy, a decoration, so we didnâ€™t change the estimation. In the end the market decided it was 18th century,â€ he said. â€œI have confidence in the market. One expert said what he said â€¦ but the real price is what the buyers decide.â€
author: [{'name': 'Kim Willsher in Paris'}]
title: â€˜A crazy storyâ€™: how a Chinese vase valued at â‚¬2,000 sold for â‚¬8m

text: New Zealandâ€™s supreme court has quashed the convictions of Peter Ellis, a Christchurch creche worker convicted of child sexual abuse in 1993 in a highly controversial case that included allegations of large-scale ritual abuse.On Friday, the court found a â€œsubstantial miscarriage of justiceâ€ had occurred. It is the first time in New Zealandâ€™s history that a conviction has been quashed posthumously â€“ Ellis died from cancer in late 2019.Until now, a personâ€™s legal proceedings have died along with them, but Ellisâ€™s appeal continued after his lawyers argued that under tikanga (MÄori customary law), a personâ€™s mana (honour) is as important in death as in life. The majority of judges ruled that the public interest factors of the case meant it was in the interests of justice to allow the appeal to go ahead.Ellis spent seven years in jail after being convicted in a 1993 jury trial on 16 counts of sexual offending against seven children who had attended the Christchurch Civic childcare centre, where he had been a teacher. The investigation began shortly after a series of similar trials investigating allegations of satanic ritual abuse at childcare centres in the US, in an era now known as the â€œsatanic panicâ€.Alan Hall case: New Zealand begins unprecedented inquiry into â€˜significant miscarriage of justiceâ€™Read moreSome of the childrenâ€™s allegations against Ellis and other childcare workers were extreme, including references to cages attached to the ceiling of the creche and large-scale rituals.The case against Ellis relied on the recollections of very young children, and many questioned its merits from the outset. Some believed the fact he was gay worked against him.While one of the children later recanted their allegations, others maintained they had been abused by Ellis for years after the trial. The court noted that the judges â€œwere conscious of the very high level of stress and public scrutiny already suffered by the complainants and their whÄnau [family] over such a long periodâ€.Ellis, who always maintained his innocence, had appealed unsuccessfully a number of times, including two failed attempts via the court of appeal and a ministerial inquiry.In 2019, the supreme court granted permission to appeal again, but Ellis died a few months later, before the hearing. In 2020, the court ruled the appeal be allowed to continue.On Friday, the court ruled the miscarriage of justice was a result of inadmissible or unbalanced expert evidence, and contaminated evidence from children, including potentially suggestive parental questioning before the complainantsâ€™ evidential interviews.Ellisâ€™s brother, Mark, said the decision had been a long time coming. â€œI wish my brother was here, because it was really what he deserved,â€ he said.However, the parents of some of the children Ellis was accused of abusing said in a statement to the New Zealand Herald that they were â€œshocked and saddenedâ€ by the decision.â€œThe trauma of not being believed over the years takes its toll. The court of public opinion is often ill-informed and the facts are lost,â€ they said.The court said the judgmentâ€™s release â€œmarks the end of a long and painful journey through the courts for the many people involved in this caseâ€, and that â€œits judgment was not to be read as a criticism of the parents, the complainants or those involved in the investigation and trialâ€.
author: [{'name': 'Tess McClure in Auckland'}]
title: New Zealand court quashes child sexual abuse conviction in landmark ruling

text:
Rivers in New South Wales are overflowing and emergency services have had to perform six flood rescues in 24 hours as another battering of heavy rain and thunderstorms descends on the east coast.The third low-pressure system was forecast to persist until Sunday morning, bringing flash flooding, landslides and damaging winds strong enough to bring down powerlines and trees.There were 63 active flood warnings across the saturated state on Saturday afternoon, and inland catchments were experiencing major flooding.At Euabalong, the Lachlan River was expected to exceed seven metres over the weekend after weeks of prolonged flooding along its lower reaches, while major flooding was occurring on the Macquarie.Melbourne received half its October rainfall in 30 minutes as weather warning issued for Bathurst 1000Read moreMajor flood levels were also expected on the Gwydir River, Namoi River, Belubula River, Mandagery Creek, Bogan River, Wollombi Brook, Lower Hunter River and Colo River.The emergency services minister, Steph Cooke, said the main areas of concern for the state emergency service (SES) were Wagga Wagga, Forbes, Warren, Gunnedah and Bathurst â€“ where thousands of race goers braved muddy, wet conditions to attend the first day of the 2022 Bathurst 1000.â€œWe are only eight days into the storm season, and, unfortunately, we are seeing flooding continuing across New South Wales,â€ Cooke said.
Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning
â€œIt is expected to do so for weeks and in fact months ahead â€¦ We are expecting to see another trough move through from Wednesday, which will impact already flooded communities â€¦ right across the west of New South Wales.â€The SES received more than 330 calls for assistance in 24 hours and performed six flood rescues, bolstered by four defence force helicopters provided by the federal government to supplement 500 personnel in the field.The Bureau of Meteorologyâ€™s Jane Golding said the rain band was starting to â€œfill inâ€ across the state.A severe weather warning was active for Newcastle, Gosford, Sydney, Wollongong, Nowra and Katoomba across the central tablelands, Hunter and metropolitan regions for damaging winds and heavy rainfall.â€œWe expect â€¦ rain rates to increase through the course of this afternoon and overnight â€¦ from Bathurst up to the Queensland border, and along the central New South Wales coast,â€ Golding said on Saturday.â€œThe good news is that this system is moving through very quickly and we should have a couple of days of reprieve after it before the next system starts to encroach on the west of the state.â€Six-hour totals of up to 70mm were expected, while damaging winds with peak gusts in excess of 90km/h were predicted along the coast. Flash flooding was already occurring in the stateâ€™s west.The assistant commissioner of the NSW SES, Dean Storey, told ABC News â€œmany moreâ€ flooding events were expected in coming months and a wet forecast lay ahead.â€œThere is definitely a flood fatigue situation across many, many parts of the state â€¦ in particular in the west and the south â€¦ who have been experiencing major flooding now for what feels like the best part of a year,â€ he said.Sign up to Guardian Australia's Morning MailFree daily newsletterOur Australian morning briefing email breaks down the key national and international stories of the day and why they matterPrivacy Notice: Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see our Privacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.â€œUnfortunately, the bureauâ€™s forecasting an above-average rainfall storm and flood season, so weâ€™re probably going to see many more events like this over the coming months.â€œ[With] that heavy rain coming on top of saturated soils and catchments and dams that are already full and overflowing [we] can really see that flooding risk escalate really, really quickly.â€The NSW premier, Dominic Perrottet, urged residents to follow SES advice and avoid driving through flood waters.â€œDonâ€™t put your life at risk,â€ he said.NSW councils call for funding boost for rain-related repairs or they will â€˜start closing roadsâ€™Read moreâ€œWe do have rivers, we do have dams that are completely at capacity, so it doesnâ€™t necessarily take heavy rainfall to create flash flooding across our state.â€In Queensland, the heaviest rainfall was expected in the Maranoa and Warrego, Darling Downs and central west districts in the stateâ€™s south-east.There were seven catchments issued with flood warnings including the lower Macintyre and Weir rivers in the border rivers, the Bokhara River in the lower Balonne River system, and the Paroo, Bulloo, and Barcoo rivers and Cooper Creek.Farther south, Victorian residents were on alert after a major downpour on Friday that dumped a monthâ€™s worth of rain on parts of the state in an hour.There were 13 flood warnings across the state including the Barwon River, with minor flooding possible in Geelong from the evening. The Loddon River and weir to Kerang was deemed a no-go zone due to flood hazards, and Grapevine Gathering â€“ a music festival in the Yarra Valley â€“ was cancelled.More than 20 requests for assistance had been attended to by SES in Victoria in 24 hours, including seven at Woodend and six in Maryborough, north-west of Melbourne.

title: NSW floods: SES performs six rescues amid 63 flood warnings and continuing rainfall

text:
A third person has been arrested after a man was shot dead in the front yard of a home in south-west Brisbane as two male suspects remain on the run.Officers from the Acacia Ridge criminal investigation branch and homicide unit arrested the 30-year-old east Brisbane man on Friday evening after he was intercepted in a vehicle at Riverview.The man has been charged with murder and will appear in Brisbane magistrates court on Saturday.Woodchipper murder trial: â€˜Thou shalt not killâ€™ message left in letterbox of accused, Brisbane court hearsRead moreOfficers also seized items of significance to the homicide investigation after two search warrants were executed on Friday evening.The two other people taken into custody are yet to be charged.Police confirmed on Saturday they were still looking for two male suspects, while investigations continued into the death of a 38-year-old Inala man.
Sign up to receive an email with the top stories from Guardian Australia every morning
The man died after being struck once in the chest at close range at a home in Cliveden Avenue, Oxley in the early hours of Tuesday morning.Detective superintendent Andrew Massingham initially alleged four men and a woman armed with a 12-gauge shotgun, and potentially a handgun, were involved in the attack.â€œThe male deceased was struck at very close range and we believe the weapon involved was a 12-gauge shotgun,â€ he told reporters on Tuesday.Massingham alleged the man had been sitting in a car near the home when the five turned up and started assaulting another man who lived at the home.The 38-year-old got out of his car and started running to the manâ€™s aid when he was shot.Sign up to Guardian Australia's Morning MailFree daily newsletterOur Australian morning briefing email breaks down the key national and international stories of the day and why they matterPrivacy Notice: Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see our Privacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Police were probing a dispute between the two men and the five suspects one to two weeks before the shooting.â€œCertainly there was significant conflict amongst the whole group,â€ Massingham said.The dispute was not related to a number of recent gang shootings in the cityâ€™s south, he said.The shooting occurred across the road from the Corinda State School less than six hours before hundreds of students were due to return to class after school holidays.A preschool and a childcare centre are also located on the same block in the quiet, mainly residential suburb.Police urged anyone with information about the manâ€™s death to contact Policelink or lodge an anonymous report through Crime Stoppers.
